Award.AwardTitle: NSF International Travel Grant for 2015 Future Directions in Spectrum Management Research Workshop

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The growth of high-speed mobile internet access has already revolutionized our lives and is expected to continue unabated. As new applications such as Machine-to-Machine (M2M), self-driving cars, and ubiquitous video appear on the horizon, rapid growth of traffic in wireless mobile and nomadic access will dwarf all other wireless applications. Therefore, design of future wireless networks that can sustain such traffic growth is an important research challenge. A critical piece of such design is spectrum management strategies that leverage maximum efficiency and maximum public benefit from the radio spectrum. This workshop will explore the key technical and policy challenges in spectrum management facing researchers in the coming decade. The proposed international travel grants will enable U.S.-based researchers to participate in these important global conversations. U.S.-based researchers will both be able to represent the U.S.'s unique perspective on spectrum management and be informed by the different approaches being adopted in Europe and elsewhere. Moreover, U.S.-based researchers will return home with a clearer sense of key research problems to guide their own future research, helping to enable the U.S. to remain at the forefront of wireless communications research.

This award will enable travel grants to be made to up to 15 U.S.-based researchers to attend the 2015 Future Directions in Spectrum Management Research Workshop. The workshop is being held in Stockholm, Sweden on September 29, 2015, co-located with IEEE DySPAN 2015. Travel grants will be made to enable U.S.-based researchers that are not presenting at IEEE DySPAN to bring a diversity of views to the workshop. A few smaller travel grants will also be made to enable DySPAN presenters to be in Stockholm for an additional day to participate in the workshop. The PI will seek to identify and make some travel awards to researchers from underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported the awarding of nine travel grants, in amounts ranging from $400 to $3000 each, to US-based researchers, enabling these researchers to participate in a workshop. The workshop, "Future Directions in Spectrum Management Research," was held in conjunction with the IEEE International Symposium on Dynamic Spectrum Access Networks (DySPAN), 2015, which was held in Stockholm, Sweden. Three of the grantees received larger awards, to enable them to travel to Sweden to participate in the workshop; the other four grantees were already planning to attend the conference, and received smaller grants to enable them to extend their trip in order to participate in the workshop. 

Spectrum policy is of critical importance in developing future wireless communications technologies as well as protecting other critical technologies (such as radar) that use the radio spectrum. Research in this area recognizes that the increasing demand for wireless communications has increased the need to use spectrum more efficiently and intensively. This workshop explored important emerging topics in spectrum management research. This research is necessary to enable future wireless technology.

All of the travel grant recipients presented papers describing their research at the workshop. The seven travel grant recipients represented six different universities (in six different states) plus one company. Two of the seven grant recipients were women.
